titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. V:30. Finished the Draft of answer to Salmon, concerning R. W. Meade— It kept me from the Office, till I was sent for to meet Baron Tuyll. He read me his despatch to Count Nesselrode giving account of the former Conference, which was correct— I told him several incidents had since occurred, to be noticed— C. Pinkney was gone to embark at Boston— P.U.S. would accept the proposal to treat of the N’West Coast question at St. Petersburg; and to send a Power and Instructions to Mr Middleton— But he relied that the Russian Government would include in the Negotiation a claim of indemnities, to the owners of the vessel turned off from the N.W. Coast by the Russian Frigate Apollo— The Baron urged that this claim should be separately and confidentially made— I said we should wish to treat in the most conciliatory manner possible on this subject— I should answer his Note on the proposal to negotiate, and had no doubt the President would consent that the claim of indemnity should be separately
made— He urged that I should not address it at-all to him, but through Mr Middleton to Count Nesselrode, to whom he would write to say that such a claim must be expected— He asked if I could without impropriety tell him the object of Randall’s Mission to Porto-Rico. I told him to procure evidence of claims to indemnity for sufferers under the decree of Morales of 15 Septr. 1821—to obtain the Florida Documents, at the Havanna, and to correspond with our naval Officers for the suppression of Pirates. I told him also of the British circular disclaiming declaration about Cuba— At the President’s. Told him of my conferences with Tuyll this day and Canning yesterday. Proposal to him to recommend to Congress at their next Session, the Establishment of a Military Post at Columbia river— He desired me to send round the Russian Minister’s Note and call a Cabinet Meeting to-morrow at 2— Dined at Petry’s. Heads of Departments all there— Gave Crawford Baron Tuyll’s note, and notified all of the Meeting. Evening party and dance at Secretary Thompson’s. Wallenstein a German Savant— Much conversation with him— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith and T. B. Johnson with me came away. No others of our family went.

2. VI.Dr. T. Watkins was here this morning, to look over some of my Letters from St Petersburg. I told him the source of some of L. Harris’s falsehoods circulated at Philadelphia, against me. He mentioned that the Florida Treaty Claim Commissioners had delivered a written opinion upon the claim of R. W. Meade— Cabinet Meeting at the President’s— Crawford, Calhoun and Thompson present. Wirt is absent— The Russian North-West Coast claim discussed and proposed negotiation at St Petersburg— Agreed to negotiate. Great diversity of opinion as to terms— Crawford is for agreeing to an English boundary at 49. North—leaving the Russian boundary to be settled between them and England. I proposed that P.U.S. should authorise instructions to our Squadron in the Pacific to protect the trade, and recommend to Congress the establishment of a Military Post at Columbia river. Calhoun thinks if any Post is established it must be strong enough to repel a possible Russian invasion— At least a regiment. I think two companies would be enough. Crawford one Battalion. Crawford thinks the Executive has no Constitutional power to protect the trade without an act of Congress. Calhoun thinks the right doubtful. Thompson
and I think it clear— Crawford thinks there is not a great interest to protect. From these diversities I am to prepare the answer to Baron Tuyll— The Meeting broke up about six— Evening at home—dull.

3. VI.L. Rice called here with another Presbyterian or Baptist Clergyman from Georgia, named Sherborough, who said he had business with me, for which he would come to the Office— R. C. Anderson came and took leave going to Baltimore, and thence to Norfolk, to embark in the John Adams for Colombia— At the Office— Coll. Torrens, with a Letter from Zozaya, who is about returning to Mexico, and leaves him as Chargé d’Affaires. Torrens says there has been a change of Government in Mexico, but he knows not yet what it is— B. O. Tyler, with Mr Bennett from Montreal. Evening solitary walk— Call at Mr Thompson’s Secy Navy to enquire. He is very ill seized suddenly this Morning with a bilious Colic— Mrs Adams continues very unwell, and George’s arm stiffens.

4. V:30. Finished at last, the draft of H. Nelson’s General Instructions. Received two Notes from P.U.S. one remarkable— Answered them. Heard Little—A.M. Luke 20.38. “For he is not a God of the dead, but of the living”: a discourse upon the immortality of the Soul— Afternoon Luke 7.22—last clause, “to the poor the gospel is preached.” Between the services, Commodores Chauncey and Morris called here; and in the Evening Dr Watkins with a paper which he gave me to read, and some parts of the views in which I thought incorrect. Received a very large Mail. Despatches from R. Rush—duplicates; and from A. Gallatin about the fisheries— Sent P.U.S. Erving’s private Letter to me of 1 Septr. 1818.

5. V:30. Began the draft of General Instructions to C. A. Rodney, as Minister to Buenos-Ayres— Coll. Torrens was here, and afterwards brought to the Office a copy of his Commission as Mexican Secretary of Legation— A young man namedcame with many warm and good recommendations from Boston for the appointment of Consul at Cadix—too late— B. L. Weld, with Letters from his father and Jos. Quincy, wanting a place here, or in the Western Country— Advice to him. Charles Walker, and his Soldier’s land Claims in Georgia— At P.U.S. Commissions to be made out for Willard Hall, as District Judge in Delaware; for T L. L. Brent as Consul at Cadix, and for S. Fry as member of the Legislative Council in Florida— Also a nephew of MrMadison’s, Macon as District Attorney in East-Florida, in place of A. Hamilton— Genl. S. Smith’s effort,
against W. Hall— It was G. W. Erving who told P.U.S. that Meade pretended to have documents from Onis and De Neuville to shew that his claims had been substituted in the Florida Negotiation for the Navigation of the Mississippi— Erving is pleading hard to go as Minister to France, and complains of having been ill-treated, because his resignation as Minister to Spain was accepted without forcing him to stay there— P.U.S. goes the day after to-morrow to Loudoun. Evening heavy, and unwillingly idle.

6. V:30. Found at the Office, the Count de Menou— His complaint against a Midshipman under Commodore Jones at Port-Mahon, for an attempt to search a French Merchant vessel for a Deserter— I read to him the answer of Captain Jones to the Governor of Port Mahon, upon the complaint of the French Consul, received from Mr Forsyth— He said he would write me a Note, concerning it— Asked me also about my Report, and argument in Senate, upon the case of John Smith of Ohio, which I found and shewed him in the National Intelligencer for 1808. I suppose he wanted it to see if it would countenance the expulsion of Manuel. Calhoun came to the Office— Wanted Pringle’s recommendation of Lee, as District Judge U.S. in South Carolina— Says the Ex-Senator Smith wants to make Mischief with the friends of Bennett— Evening call on S. Thompson Secy of the Navy, who is convalescent— Urges the immediate preparation of Instructions to R. C. Anderson, to go in the John Adams— Mrs de Bresson charmed with Boston— George first able to wear his coat, since his accident.

7. V:30.Mr Elgar, Commissioner of the Public Buildings called yesterday to consult me upon an Inscription for the tomb of Elbridge Gerry, to be erected, by an Act of Congress at their last Session— Elgar’s Inscription was very short, and without attempt at any manifestation of Sentiment. I only advised him to add a single line, stating that he was one of the Signers of the Declaration of Independence— At the Office this day, came MessrsSharp and Bowles, Baptist Clergymen from Boston and Salem; attending a triennial general Convention of Baptist Ministers now assembled here— Mr Sherborough came with a Letter from a friend asking for one of the Yazoo claim Documents. I thought there had been a Law passed at the late Session of Congress requiring of the Secretary of State to deliver them, but could not find it— I offered him a
copy of the document if it could be found— He said he would take it— General Jesup, came with Charles Savage formerly of Barnstable, Massachusetts, but now of Louisville Kentucky, which he intends to quit— Dr Thornton came and recommended an arbitrator in a Patent case between Dalliba and Brown— Proposed De Witt Clinton, and the Ex-chancellor Lansing— I advised the latter— Petitions to P.U.S. for the discharge from prison of Drane and Hayre—granted. H. Nelson here— Ready to go; but the frigate and Mr Rodney are not. Nelson goes with P.U.S. to Loudoun to-morrow— Evening solitary walk. Addington here. Lines in the New-York Statesmen of the 5th.Johnson Hellen came.

8. V:30. The President went to Loudoun. Mr H. Nelson came to tell me that as soon as I shall be ready to despatch him with his Instructions, he will go to Philadelphia— The Congress Frigate will not be ready to sail from Newcastle these ten days. Mr C. Savage called again. Going to-morrow for Barnstable. Intended to apply for the Consulate of Cadix. Will apply for something else— Charles Walker again at the Office, about his Soldier’s Lands in Georgia— Day at the Office wasted upon the current business, and reading the Mail despatches— Evening Solitary walk.

9. V:30. Finished Draft of General Instructions to C. A. Rodney. Vice-President Tompkins and a Mr Butler here— Tompkins comes for the Settlement of his Accounts. Butler, is a partner of Mr Van Buren as a lawyer, at Albany. At the Office, the Baron de Tuyll, the Russian Minister came, and thanks me for my note accepting the proposal of negotiating about the North West Coast questions at St. Petersburg— And asked me to forward a packet of despatches for him to Count Lieven, at London. He will send it to me to-morrow— Letter from my Son John— He, with two thirds of his Class dismissed from College. Letter also from my brother.

10. V:30. Began Draft of General Instructions to R. C. Anderson, as Minister to the Republic of Colombia— Wrote to P.U.S. and sent him that of the Instructions to Rodney— Dr Sewall here—and T Watkins, with a Letter from the Florida Treaty Claim Commissioners, and an enclosure from R. W. Meade, giving a list of Documents to be called for from the Spanish Government— Watkins shewed me also a Manuscript of his own, in which I pointed out to him an inaccuracy— At the Office, I had a visit from about 30 Baptist Clergymen, who are here at their triennial convention, among whom are Dr Staughton and also Dr Baldwin of Boston— They wished to see the curiosities— The
original Declaration of Independence was shewn them, but Mr Bailey who had the key to the Treaties was absent, and they could not see them. A Mr Hastings, of Boston returning from New-Orleans, called— Was a fellow passenger with me from New-York to Providence in 1821. Baron Tuyll, sent me his Packet, which I sent to Mr Cazenove at Alexandria, with a Messenger’s Passport, and undercover to R. Rush— Johnson Hellen returned to Rockville— Evening with Mrs Adams, and T. B. Johnson at Mrs Decatur’s— The Diplomatic Corps there— Chess with G. Hay—

11. V:45.G. Hay here; to enquire of a Conversation between me and C. F. Mercer, about his Slave-trade Pirate Bill— Mercer mentioned it to Mr Smyth, who wanted immediately to attack me about it in the Newspapers. Mercer objected to this, and told Hay of it yesterday. I told Hay the substance of the Conversation, and he said it agreed with what Mercer had said of it— Hay thought the Pirate Act Unconstitutional—Congress having as he says no right under the power to define Piracy, to make such an Offence committed on Land— I said I had not brought my mind to that conclusion; if it was an act committed by landing from the Sea—and cited the case of Paul Jones, and Lord Selkirk’s plate— Heard Little A.M. 2— Corinthians 13.9. “and this also we wish, even your perfection”— Then a Lecture, in which he argued that Silas, and Sylvanus and Luke were the same person; author of the Gospel of Luke and of the Acts— Visit after Church to Vice-President Tompkins, and Butler; at Dowson’s— They go to-morrow— Little’s afternoon Sermon was from Romans 2–3— [“]And thinkest thou this O man, that judgest them which do such things, and doest the same, that thou shalt escape the judgment of God.” Attended after Church the funeral of David Young, Mr Bailey’s father in Law, who died last Night. Long address of Mr M’Cormick at the grave. Past seven when I got home to dinner. Mr and Mrs Frye and Mrs W. S. Smith here after dinner.

12. V:30.S. L. Gouverneur here. Goes again for New-York tomorrow. Spoke of the settlement of the Vice-President’s Accounts to be made by the President. At the Office— Parish came from Mr Canning, with papers from New-Brunswick and Nova-Scotia, claiming a reciprocal abolition of all discriminating duties. The New Brunswick Proclamation follows the words of our Statute, but evidently with a different understanding of its meaning, from ours— The Halifax papers shew that there is a discriminating Tonnage duty in favour of the Vessels of the Province, still in force there— Parish left a minute with me requesting an answer to Mr.
Canning’s last Note on the Subject— General Brown came, to urge for the appointment of Ambrose Spencer, to the vacant seat in the Bench of the Supreme Court U.S.— The General is a warm friend of Mr Spencer’s, but seems not to understand the politics of New-York— Evening at home, assorting Newspapers, and reading J. B. Prevost’s Letters.

13. V:30.Mr Insinger called here, a day or two since with a duplicate of David Parish’s Letter from Vienna 1. Feby last, resigning the Office of Consul at Antwerpe. Insinger applied for the appointment himself— I told him it was under promise to a native Citizen U.S— I called at Mr Calhoun’s Office to enquire about the condition of the Florida Cannon, which we have agreed to give up to Spain, or pay for— He thinks it would be best to give them up, as they are not of the same Calibre with ours— At the Office. G. Hay came. Spoke of the Bill for settling the Vice-President’s Accounts, which he disapproves—and thinks Tompkins came here personally to press it upon the President— Mr. Canning called. The British Commissioner upon the Slave Indemnity Commission is George Jackson— The Arbitrator Mr M’Tavish. Jackson to come out with the April Packet— Canning urged warmly for an answer to his last note about the abolition of the discriminating duties. I promised one if possible to-morrow— Says the British Government wish to refer the Boundary question disagreed upon by the 5th. Article Ghent Treaty Commissioners, and sounded me, as to the Sovereign to be selected— Various Conversation about it— I am to write of it to the President— Something said of the North-west Coast question. I told him we had agreed to send powers to Mr Middleton to treat of it— Evening walk. Assorting papers, and drowsy idle.

14. V:30.Mr Lemuel Sawyer, M.C. from North-Carolina called upon me to ask my opinion of a manuscript Volume, called Spirit of antient Authors written by him, and which some days since he left here in my absence, for my inspection— I had not seen it; and it was not immediately found— At dinner time, it was discovered by George— A Baptist Clergyman, Mr Somers came with a Subscription for a Baptist Church in the City of New-York. Mr M’Gowan, recommended by Mr H. Nelson, came to apply for employment. At the Office— Met Dr Tucker who introduced to me General Pegram the Marshal from the Eastern District of Virginia— He had some enquiries and some claims, from the taking of the Census— Draft of Answer to G. Canning about the colonial intercourse, and discriminating duties— Evening walk. Mr Canning called to see Mrs Adams who was at her Sister Smith’s— He is going to England on a leave of absence. Letter from my Son John about my father. Letter to W. C. Somerville.

15. V:30.Mr G. Hay called this morning with a Letter from a friend of his, applying for the appointment of Consul at Cadix. I told him T. L. L. Brent was already appointed— I spoke of his agency under the Slave Indemnity Commission, and asked him to call at my Office, for some conversation with him concerning it— He spoke of Wythe in the Richmond Enquirer— Brannan came to ask for employment to write for the Department of State— Copying the Record of the Laws— At the Office, Dr. Thornton and Stone came about the Patent parchments and Mr. B. T. Watts of South-Carolina, to apply for the appointment of Secretary of the Legation to Chili— He says Mr Kennedy intends to decline— I prepared the draft of personal Instructions for C. A. Rodney— Evening with all the family at Mr Frye’s. T. B. Johnson dined there— I walked there with George, and home alone.

16. VI:L. Sawyer here. About returning to North-Carolina, to secure his re-election to Congress— His views of North-Carolina Politics— Judge Anderson the Comptroller—to recommend M’Gowan for Employment. At the Office— Cazenove from Alexandria—for Certificates to authenticate a power of Attorney from him to his Agent at Geneva— Letters to P.U.S—to H. Nelson at Philadelphia, about the uniform; and to L. Cheves and H. Seawell— Evening party and Ball, for Hersant’s wedding. Upwards of 100 persons— Sharp conversation with Canning; who wants yet further explanations of the Colonial intercourse Law.

17. VI: At the Office; still preparing Instructions for H. Nelson—C. A. Rodney and R. C. Anderson— The subjects swell as I proceed— “The line too labours and the verse moves slow[”]— Sent P.U.S. the part already drafted of Anderson’s Instructions— Compared the papers to go with the Instructions to Nelson. Found several still wanting— Dined at Captain Chauncey’s with T. B. Johnson— Corps Diplomatique there— Summer here.

18. V:30. Heard Little—A.M. Acts 2.32.33. This “Jesus hath God raised up, whereof we are all witnesses— Therefore being by the right hand of God exalted, and having received of the Father the promise of the Holy Ghost, he hath shed forth this, which ye now see and hear.” An excellent Historical Whitsunday Sermon, tracing it to the Jewish Feast of Weeks, and explaining the meaning of the term Holy Ghost according to the Unitarian Creed— After Church I visited Mr Calhoun and found him sick in bed, but convalescent— He was seized on
Friday with violent chills and fever, for having prematurely cast off his flannels— Hoped to escape the return of the fever this Evening— Long conversation with him on Politics— South-America, St. Salvador Deputies, Spain, Great-Britain, Holy Alliance and Governor Wolcott’s Message— Mail— Letters from Mexico— Private from Wilkinson— Little’s Sermon P.M. Revelat. 14.6.7. “And I saw another angel fly in the midst of heaven, having the everlasting gospel to preach unto them that dwell on the earth, and to every nation, and kindred, and tongue, and people— Saying with a loud voice, Fear God, and give glory to him; for the hour of his judgment is come: and worship him that made heaven and earth, and the sea, and the fountains of waters.” The drift of this discourse was an argument to shew that the Book of the Apocalypse though prophetic is unintelligible, and that we have no proof of the existence of such beings as angels— Wrote this Evening to President Kirkland.

19. V. Bath in the Potowmac with Antoine— Mr Samuel Carusi came to tell me that he wished to go to Italy for the settlement of certain private affairs, and would be glad to be appointed Consul of the United States at Palermo— Mr Lindsley came to the Office to ask if there was no place for him, and Mr M’Gowan for employment— Mr D. Brent was absent— Day after Whitsunday— Confirmations at the Catholic Church— Mr Canning came— Long conversation with him, about the Colonial Intercourse— His anxiety to obtain concessions— Told me he should wish to take leave of the President after his return from Virginia. Says the Climate here does not agree with him— Spoke again of the fifth Article of the Ghent Treaty and the Arbitrator. Of South America, recognition and freedom of Commerce. Case of the Lord Collingwood. Has copies of the papers— Shy about shewing them— Ride after dinner with Mrs AdamsMary Hellen and George— Mr. and Mrs de Bresson, W. Lee and his two daughters. Evening visitors.

20. IV:30. Bath with Antoine— Mr Alfred Conkling was here, late a member of Congress from the State of New-York— Came to urge the appointment of Ambrose Spencer as Judge, U.S. Supreme Court. I had received a Letter from him concerning it before— Long Conversation with him— I told him what I thought would be the difficulties in the way— His feelings with regard to Van-Buren— At the Office— Coyle to protest a Note for $3000 of Jas Simpson late Consul at Morocco; given in Decr. 1819. and presented now here for payment— Mr Kerr came and protested it. YoungWatkins, brought
recommendations for the appointment of Secretary to the Mission to Chili— Kennedy intending to resign— Baron Tuyl—asked Letters for Baron Maltitz going to Charleston S.C. Pensacola, and New-Orleans— I advised that he should go at another Season— The Baron urged a soothing publication, concerning the North-west Coast questions and spoke of the late violent Newspaper paragraphs—particularly one of the 14th. in the City Gazette; but extracted from another— I told the Baron I had delayed the notice to let the feeling at the recent incident pass over—but would remember it in due time— Oppressive heat this Evening. Thunder Shower.

21. V:30.Mrs Adams and her brother; Mary Hellen and George went and passed the day at Alexandria— Dr Thornton here. Spoke of his conversation yesterday with Mr Calhoun about the Presidency, and brought me an Article in the Quarterly Review, about the disputed trinitarian text. At the Office— Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy— Anxious for the departure of the John Adams— I told him I must send the draft of R. C. Anderson’s instructions to P.U.S— Spoke of the complaints against our Captain Stewart and Spence— More papers to send to Nelson— Mr Parish called from Mr Canning with a copy of the Sentence in the case of Lord Collingwood— Dined alone. Despatched J. M. Baker with the Instructions to Nelson and Rodney. Evening Solitary walk— There was a man named Burr came to me yesterday as a deputy from 3 or 4. wishing to set up a newspaper and needing a loan. I declined— Letter of apology from S. Smith.

22. V:30. Bath in the Potowmack with Antoine. W. T. Robinson came for a subscription, for Gregory’s Dictionary of Arts and Sciences— R. S. Coxe for the balance awarded to Gould by Mr Southard. I told him I could not allow for what I had never submitted to Mr Southard— At the Office— Calhoun brought a Letter from . . . to him, concerning Mr Read of Delaware, and papers enclosed concerning a charge against him— He is also a candidate for the Office of District Judge in Delaware; but the appointment of W. Hall is already made. Voluminous Mail— Yesterday finished the draft of General Instructions to R. C. Anderson, and began draft to R. Rush upon Colonial Intercourse. Petry here this Evening. Gave me a copy of Mr Hyde de Neuville’s opinion upon the expulsion of Manuel—from the Author. Letter from C. Hughes London— British Parliament papers.

23. VI. Day without interruption at home or at the Office, but under a severe pressure in examining, and discussing the Colonial Intercourse
subject. Excessively dry and intricate— Letter from W. Duane Bogota— Wrote to P.U.S. and to Govr Preston— Recommendations of R. H. Ives to R. Rush— Evening walk with George— Mrs Adams and her brother spent it at Mrs Decatur’s. Johnson Hellen here.

24. V:45. The Count de Menou was at the Office, and spoke of the complaint of a French Master of a vessel at Port-Mahon, against a Midshipman from one of our Frigates; for an insult upon the French flag, and violation of the Spanish territorial jurisdiction— I told him I would send him a copy of Captn Jones’s Letter; disavowing the act of the Midshipman; a boyish indiscretion, and said I should have occasion to mention to him a similar complaint on our part—that of the interrupted fishing vessels on the Coast of Newfoundland— The French Minister Chateaubriand, after a discussion upon this subject with Mr Gallatin stated that he had instructed the Charge d’Affaires here to give explanations concerning it— Menou said he had not received such Instructions— Menou asked me also several questions as to the effect of our Treaties with Spain in relation to the principle of free ships free goods— I told him in its application to France it would depend on the question whether France recognized it or not— Evening walk.

25. V:30. Heard Mr Little A.M. Luke 10.21. [“]In that hour Jesus rejoiced in Spirit, and said, I thank thee O Father, Lord of Heaven and Earth, that thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast revealed them unto babes: even so Father; for so it seemed good in thy sight.” The principal argument of this discourse was against the possibility of a double nature in Christ; because nothing can have more than one nature— But has not man two Natures; an animal perishable nature in common with the Brutes; and an immortal Nature in common with the Angels?— After Sermon there was a Lecture; in which he noticed my objection to his argument that Luke was Silas— He also mentioned the discordance between the 24th. Chapter of Luke and the 28th. of Matthew, which last he considered as spurious— Mr Salomon of the Treasury called upon me—to enquire as to Mr Gallatin’s return to this Country— Afternoon heard Mr Baker— Revelations 22.3. “And there shall be no more curse”— Evening walk with Mrs Adams.

26. V: At the Office— Mr Baker the Minister of the Presbyterian Church, came to enquire if I would act as a trustee; which I declined. He asked if my Son George would serve; for which I referred him to himself; observing that in two or three Months George would go to reside at Boston— I took a solitary walk after dinner, being still oppressed with my public business. Mr J. M. Baker returned from Philadelphia, and brought me Letters from H. Nelson, and C. A. Rodney.

27. V. A Mr Benjamin Fry of Rhode-Island came here with a claim and papers, about the loss of a vessel captured by the French in December 1800. for which he is yet seeking indemnity— A very desperate case— Mr R. C. Anderson came— I had a long conversation with him relating to his Instructions— He was yesterday from Baltimore, and returns thither to-morrow. General Macomb called; going to examine the Cadets at West-Point— At the Office— Count de Menou. Questions about our Treaty with Spain, and the form of Passport. Answered Letter from C. A. Rodney. T. B. Johnson dined at Mrs Decatur’s and Mary Hellen remained there— Mr Baker the Presbyterian Minister, with Mr Handy and Mr Hand, came with a notice, that I had been chosen Trustee of the Church, and urged my acceptance— I promised an answer by Thursday— W. Lee was here in the Evening. To solicit an appointment for W. Tudor at Lima— Solitary walk.

28. V:15. Sat to King for my Portrait. Dr Thornton came in with a Patent question, and an opinion of Judge W. P. Van Ness— General Brown, sitting also for his Portrait. At the Office— A Mr Sherman from Georgia; originally from New-York. State of Politics in Georgia. Answer to a complaint from Menou— Evening walk alone. Epigrammatic.

29. V:30— Second Sitting to King. P.U.S. returned. Called at his house with the despatches from A. Gallatin— Calhoun came in— The President came here direct from Albemarle, and did not receive the last part of R. C. Anderson’s Instructions— Mr Baker the Minister, at the Office. I accepted the appointment of Trustee to the second Presbyterian Church, and attended the Meeting at the Church. Joseph Lovell chosen President. H. Forrest Secretary.Handy Treasurer— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us. Mr Frye here this Evening— Also Dr Thornton.

30. V:15— Third sitting to King. General Brown came in— His opinions on Spanish and European Politics— His confidence in the progress of liberal principles— A Mrs Lewis came for a pardon for W. Wood, a prisoner at Philadelphia, ordered by the President— At the Office. Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy— Urgent for the departure of R. C. Anderson. The John Adams waiting for him at Norfolk— Porter much in want of the Ship and men— J. L. Glase came to solicit the appointment of Consul at Hamburg in case of a vacancy— At P.U.S— Took with me the
remainder of the Draft of Instructions, to R. C. Anderson— Talk with him about the appointment of a Judge of the Supreme Court— Walk in the Evening— Mrs Adams and her brother at Mrs Decatur’s. Letter to S. Smith.

31. V:30. Fourth sitting to King— George is also sitting— Finished the Draft of Instructions to R. Rush upon the Colonial intercourse, and began one upon other points— T. B. Johnson went to stay at Mr Frye’s— At the Office— Stackelberg— Going to pass some days with judge Washington at Mount Vernon— Has Letters from Engeström about the anonymous Letter conspiracy in Sweden— Calhoun— Has a Letter from Poinsett who wants an immediate appointment of a Minister to Mexico— Letter from W. Taylor— At P.U.S— He also thinks of appointing a Minister to Mexico. James Brown? N. Edwards? Draft of Instructions to R. C. Anderson revised— George dined at Mr Canning’s. Evening walk. Mrs Adams unwell.
Day— Same as last Month— Instructions to C. A. Rodney, and R. C. Anderson, and those to R. Rush on the Colonial Intercourse have absorbed the Month.
